title: Siegfried & Roy turn down six figures to fly four new cubs to UAE
text:
Launch slideshow » 
For 12-year-old Emma Goldsberry of the Make-a-Wish Foundation, it’s a dream come true thanks to Siegfried & Roy, masters of the impossible. 
On Thursday afternoon, she was appointed Cubs Child Ambassador of Conservation taking care of the magicians’ four new tiger cubs Hirah, Maharani, Liberty and Justice. 
The newest additions to Siegfried & Roy’s Secret Garden and Dolphin Habitat at the Mirage were born Aug. 5. 
Now 11 weeks old, they have gone from a birth weight of just 2 pounds apiece to nearly 20 pounds, and Siegfried revealed that he visits them quietly and privately every day: 
“I love to see them. I don’t have to come, but I do because I want to. We keep it quiet because I don’t want to commercialize it. I get a real high from being there. I come home and tell Roy all the stories, and that’s a real lift for both of us. 
“We have people come from all over the world. They all talk to me. Sometimes they see me, and it’s amazing we have been away from the stage for over 12 years, but they remember the day 20 years ago they came to see the show even before that.” 
Roy revealed that the duo have just turned down a six-figure offer to fly to the United Arab Emirates with the cubs for a rich oil sheik to meet them. “Our family is not for sale,” said Roy. He’s recovered well from recent foot surgery and is thinking of a vacation to Colombia. 
“We are proud to live in Las Vegas, the greatest city in the world,” Siegfried continued. “When you see a white tiger, you are blessed and will be happy forever. We have been and are. 
“Las Vegas has been very good to us because it’s where we saw all our dreams come true, and we have tried to be good to it in return. These have been very happy years for us.” 
Little Emma from Bristol, Conn., was thrilled to meet the two magicians — but more enamored by the little cubs. As part of her Make-a-Wish trip granted by Siegfried & Roy, she was able to swim with the dolphins at the Mirage. 
Visitors can see the cubs daily from noon to 4 p.m. as part of their program dedicated to the protection, conservation and preservation of endangered animals, with a particular focus on big cats — tigers, lions, cheetahs, panthers and leopards. 
Our thanks to contributing photographer Tom Donoghue for his photo gallery.
